property.name: org.eclipse.equinox.p2.description
property.value: Feature modeling is part of FeatureIDE, but it can also be used separately. The plugins give you the ability to graphically model feature diagrams, to import and export them into several formats, e.g., XML, PDF, JPG, or GUIDSL. There is also an infrastructure to perform automated analysis and reasoning using SAT4J.

property.name: org.eclipse.equinox.p2.description
property.value:
The Colored Integrated Development Environment (CIDE) is a software product line tool for analyzing and decomposing legacy code. It follows the paradigm of virtual separation of concerns, i.e., developers do not physically extract the feature code, but just annotate code fragments inside the original code and use tool support for views and navigation. For annotation, background colors are used, so that code fragments belonging to a feature are shown with a background color; hence the name.
CIDE is a research project. It is used in various branches of software engineering research for feature-oriented development, e.g., granularity of feature extensions, safe composition, feature scoping, extractive SPL adoption model, language-independent feature-decomposition, feature interaction analysis, feature location/feature mining, feature modularity, and many more.

instructions.instruction: true

property.name: org.eclipse.equinox.p2.description
property.value:
The Colored Integrated Development Environment (CIDE) is a software product line tool for analyzing and decomposing legacy code. It follows the paradigm of virtual separation of concerns, i.e., developers do not physically extract the feature code, but just annotate code fragments inside the original code and use tool support for views and navigation. For annotation, background colors are used, so that code fragments belonging to a feature are shown with a background color; hence the name.
CIDE is a research project. It is used in various branches of software engineering research for feature-oriented development, e.g., granularity of feature extensions, safe composition, feature scoping, extractive SPL adoption model, language-independent feature-decomposition, feature interaction analysis, feature location/feature mining, feature modularity, and many more.

licenses.license:
CIDE is provided as a research prototype as is. Source code can be requested for research purposes by email.
THIS SOFTWARE IS PROVIDED BY THE COPYRIGHT HOLDERS AND CONTRIBUTORS "AS IS" AND ANY EXPRESS OR IMPLIED WARRANTIES, INCLUDING, BUT NOT LIMITED TO, THE IMPLIED WARRANTIES OF MERCHANTABILITY AND FITNESS FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE ARE DISCLAIMED. IN NO EVENT SHALL THE COPYRIGHT OWNER OR CONTRIBUTORS BE LIABLE FOR ANY DIRECT, INDIRECT, INCIDENTAL, SPECIAL, EXEMPLARY, OR CONSEQUENTIAL DAMAGES (INCLUDING, BUT NOT LIMITED TO, PROCUREMENT OF SUBSTITUTE GOODS OR SERVICES; LOSS OF USE, DATA, OR PROFITS; OR BUSINESS INTERRUPTION) HOWEVER CAUSED AND ON ANY THEORY OF LIABILITY, WHETHER IN CONTRACT, STRICT LIABILITY, OR TORT (INCLUDING NEGLIGENCE OR OTHERWISE) ARISING IN ANY WAY OUT OF THE USE OF THIS SOFTWARE, EVEN IF ADVISED OF THE POSSIBILITY OF SUCH DAMAGE.

property.name: org.eclipse.equinox.p2.description
property.value:
The Colored Integrated Development Environment (CIDE) is a software product line tool for analyzing and decomposing legacy code. It follows the paradigm of virtual separation of concerns, i.e., developers do not physically extract the feature code, but just annotate code fragments inside the original code and use tool support for views and navigation. For annotation, background colors are used, so that code fragments belonging to a feature are shown with a background color; hence the name.
CIDE is a research project. It is used in various branches of software engineering research for feature-oriented development, e.g., granularity of feature extensions, safe composition, feature scoping, extractive SPL adoption model, language-independent feature-decomposition, feature interaction analysis, feature location/feature mining, feature modularity, and many more.

licenses.license:

property.name: org.eclipse.equinox.p2.description
property.value:
Java Editor for CIDE, based on the JDT Editor. With syntax highlighting, type-checking, etc. Open Java files with the "Colored Compilation Unit Editor".
Additionally import and export of annotated Java code to AHEAD, FeatureHouse, AspectJ, CPP, and Munge is provided (experimental)

property.name: org.eclipse.equinox.p2.description
property.value:
The Colored Integrated Development Environment (CIDE) is a software product line tool for analyzing and decomposing legacy code. It follows the paradigm of virtual separation of concerns, i.e., developers do not physically extract the feature code, but just annotate code fragments inside the original code and use tool support for views and navigation. For annotation, background colors are used, so that code fragments belonging to a feature are shown with a background color; hence the name.
CIDE is a research project. It is used in various branches of software engineering research for feature-oriented development, e.g., granularity of feature extensions, safe composition, feature scoping, extractive SPL adoption model, language-independent feature-decomposition, feature interaction analysis, feature location/feature mining, feature modularity, and many more.

instructions.instruction: true

property.name: org.eclipse.equinox.p2.description
property.value:
The Colored Integrated Development Environment (CIDE) is a software product line tool for analyzing and decomposing legacy code. It follows the paradigm of virtual separation of concerns, i.e., developers do not physically extract the feature code, but just annotate code fragments inside the original code and use tool support for views and navigation. For annotation, background colors are used, so that code fragments belonging to a feature are shown with a background color; hence the name.
CIDE is a research project. It is used in various branches of software engineering research for feature-oriented development, e.g., granularity of feature extensions, safe composition, feature scoping, extractive SPL adoption model, language-independent feature-decomposition, feature interaction analysis, feature location/feature mining, feature modularity, and many more.

instructions.instruction: true

licenses.license:
CIDE is provided as a research prototype as is. Source code can be requested for research purposes by email.
THIS SOFTWARE IS PROVIDED BY THE COPYRIGHT HOLDERS AND CONTRIBUTORS "AS IS" AND ANY EXPRESS OR IMPLIED WARRANTIES, INCLUDING, BUT NOT LIMITED TO, THE IMPLIED WARRANTIES OF MERCHANTABILITY AND FITNESS FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE ARE DISCLAIMED. property.name: org.eclipse.equinox.p2.description
property.value:
Java Editor for CIDE, based on the JDT Editor. With syntax highlighting, type-checking, etc. Open Java files with the "Colored Compilation Unit Editor".
Additionally import and export of annotated Java code to AHEAD, FeatureHouse, AspectJ, CPP, and Munge is provided (experimental)

property.name: org.eclipse.equinox.p2.description
property.value: Provides a number of colored example projects in various languages originating from various projects and case studies.

unit.copyright: Copyright (c) 2006-2008, Christian Kästner, University of Magdeburg, Germany All rights reserved.

property.name: org.eclipse.equinox.p2.description
property.value:
The Colored Integrated Development Environment (CIDE) is a software product line tool for analyzing and decomposing legacy code. It follows the paradigm of virtual separation of concerns, i.e., developers do not physically extract the feature code, but just annotate code fragments inside the original code and use tool support for views and navigation. For annotation, background colors are used, so that code fragments belonging to a feature are shown with a background color; hence the name.
CIDE is a research project. It is used in various branches of software engineering research for feature-oriented development, e.g., granularity of feature extensions, safe composition, feature scoping, extractive SPL adoption model, language-independent feature-decomposition, feature interaction analysis, feature location/feature mining, feature modularity, and many more.

property.name: org.eclipse.equinox.p2.description
property.value:
The Colored Integrated Development Environment (CIDE) is a software product line tool for analyzing and decomposing legacy code. It follows the paradigm of virtual separation of concerns, i.e., developers do not physically extract the feature code, but just annotate code fragments inside the original code and use tool support for views and navigation. For annotation, background colors are used, so that code fragments belonging to a feature are shown with a background color; hence the name.
CIDE is a research project. It is used in various branches of software engineering research for feature-oriented development, e.g., granularity of feature extensions, safe composition, feature scoping, extractive SPL adoption model, language-independent feature-decomposition, feature interaction analysis, feature location/feature mining, feature modularity, and many more.

licenses.license:
CIDE is provided as a research prototype as is. Source code can be requested for research purposes by email.
THIS SOFTWARE IS PROVIDED BY THE COPYRIGHT HOLDERS AND CONTRIBUTORS "AS IS" AND ANY EXPRESS OR IMPLIED WARRANTIES, INCLUDING, BUT NOT LIMITED TO, THE IMPLIED WARRANTIES OF MERCHANTABILITY AND FITNESS FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE ARE DISCLAIMED. IN NO EVENT SHALL THE COPYRIGHT OWNER OR CONTRIBUTORS BE LIABLE FOR ANY DIRECT, INDIRECT, INCIDENTAL, SPECIAL, EXEMPLARY, OR CONSEQUENTIAL DAMAGES (INCLUDING, BUT NOT LIMITED TO, PROCUREMENT OF SUBSTITUTE GOODS OR SERVICES; LOSS OF USE, DATA, OR PROFITS; OR BUSINESS INTERRUPTION) HOWEVER CAUSED AND ON ANY THEORY OF LIABILITY, WHETHER IN CONTRACT, STRICT LIABILITY, OR TORT (INCLUDING NEGLIGENCE OR OTHERWISE) ARISING IN ANY WAY OUT OF THE USE OF THIS SOFTWARE, EVEN IF ADVISED OF THE POSSIBILITY OF SUCH DAMAGE.

property.name: org.eclipse.equinox.p2.description
property.value:
The Colored Integrated Development Environment (CIDE) is a software product line tool for analyzing and decomposing legacy code. It follows the paradigm of virtual separation of concerns, i.e., developers do not physically extract the feature code, but just annotate code fragments inside the original code and use tool support for views and navigation. For annotation, background colors are used, so that code fragments belonging to a feature are shown with a background color; hence the name.
CIDE is a research project. It is used in various branches of software engineering research for feature-oriented development, e.g., granularity of feature extensions, safe composition, feature scoping, extractive SPL adoption model, language-independent feature-decomposition, feature interaction analysis, feature location/feature mining, feature modularity, and many more.

licenses.license:
CIDE is provided as a research prototype as is. Source code can be requested for research purposes by email.
THIS SOFTWARE IS PROVIDED BY THE COPYRIGHT HOLDERS AND CONTRIBUTORS "AS IS" AND ANY EXPRESS OR IMPLIED WARRANTIES, INCLUDING, BUT NOT LIMITED TO, THE IMPLIED WARRANTIES OF MERCHANTABILITY AND FITNESS FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE ARE DISCLAIMED. property.value:

Additionally import and export of annotated Java code to AHEAD, FeatureHouse, AspectJ, CPP, and Munge is provided (experimental)

instructions.instruction: Bundle-ManifestVersion: 2 Bundle-Version: 0.1.0.200906231555 Export-Package: tmp.generated_python Require-Bundle: de.ovgu.cide.ast,de.ovgu.cide.core Manifest-Version: 1.0 Bundle-SymbolicName: de.ovgu.cide.language.python;singleton:=true Bundle-Name: CIDE Language Plugin for Python Bundle-Vendor: Christian Kaestner, University of Magdeburg

property.name: org.eclipse.equinox.p2.description
property.value:
The Colored Integrated Development Environment (CIDE) is a software product line tool for analyzing and decomposing legacy code. It follows the paradigm of virtual separation of concerns, i.e., developers do not physically extract the feature code, but just annotate code fragments inside the original code and use tool support for views and navigation. For annotation, background colors are used, so that code fragments belonging to a feature are shown with a background color; hence the name.
CIDE is a research project. It is used in various branches of software engineering research for feature-oriented development, e.g., granularity of feature extensions, safe composition, feature scoping, extractive SPL adoption model, language-independent feature-decomposition, feature interaction analysis, feature location/feature mining, feature modularity, and many more.

instructions.instruction: true

licenses.license:
CIDE is provided as a research prototype as is. Source code can be requested for research purposes by email.
THIS SOFTWARE IS PROVIDED BY THE COPYRIGHT HOLDERS AND CONTRIBUTORS "AS IS" AND ANY EXPRESS OR IMPLIED WARRANTIES, INCLUDING, BUT NOT LIMITED TO, THE IMPLIED WARRANTIES OF MERCHANTABILITY AND FITNESS FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE ARE DISCLAIMED. IN NO EVENT SHALL THE COPYRIGHT OWNER OR CONTRIBUTORS BE LIABLE FOR ANY DIRECT, INDIRECT, INCIDENTAL, SPECIAL, EXEMPLARY, OR CONSEQUENTIAL DAMAGES (INCLUDING, BUT NOT LIMITED TO, PROCUREMENT OF SUBSTITUTE GOODS OR SERVICES; LOSS OF USE, DATA, OR PROFITS; OR BUSINESS INTERRUPTION) HOWEVER CAUSED AND ON ANY THEORY OF LIABILITY, WHETHER IN CONTRACT, STRICT LIABILITY, OR TORT (INCLUDING NEGLIGENCE OR OTHERWISE) ARISING IN ANY WAY OUT OF THE USE OF THIS SOFTWARE, EVEN IF ADVISED OF THE POSSIBILITY OF SUCH DAMAGE.

property.name: org.eclipse.equinox.p2.description
property.value: Feature modeling is part of FeatureIDE, but it can also be used separately. The plugins give you the ability to graphically model feature diagrams, to import and export them into several formats, e.g., XML, PDF, JPG, or GUIDSL. There is also an infrastructure to perform automated analysis and reasoning using SAT4J.

instructions.instruction: true

property.name: org.eclipse.equinox.p2.description
property.value:
The Colored Integrated Development Environment (CIDE) is a software product line tool for analyzing and decomposing legacy code. It follows the paradigm of virtual separation of concerns, i.e., developers do not physically extract the feature code, but just annotate code fragments inside the original code and use tool support for views and navigation. For annotation, background colors are used, so that code fragments belonging to a feature are shown with a background color; hence the name.
CIDE is a research project. It is used in various branches of software engineering research for feature-oriented development, e.g., granularity of feature extensions, safe composition, feature scoping, extractive SPL adoption model, language-independent feature-decomposition, feature interaction analysis, feature location/feature mining, feature modularity, and many more.

instructions.instruction: true

property.name: org.eclipse.equinox.p2.description
property.value:
Java Editor for CIDE, based on the JDT Editor. With syntax highlighting, type-checking, etc. Open Java files with the "Colored Compilation Unit Editor".
Additionally import and export of annotated Java code to AHEAD, FeatureHouse, AspectJ, CPP, and Munge is provided (experimental)

property.name: org.eclipse.equinox.p2.description
property.value:
The Colored Integrated Development Environment (CIDE) is a software product line tool for analyzing and decomposing legacy code. It follows the paradigm of virtual separation of concerns, i.e., developers do not physically extract the feature code, but just annotate code fragments inside the original code and use tool support for views and navigation. For annotation, background colors are used, so that code fragments belonging to a feature are shown with a background color; hence the name.
CIDE is a research project. It is used in various branches of software engineering research for feature-oriented development, e.g., granularity of feature extensions, safe composition, feature scoping, extractive SPL adoption model, language-independent feature-decomposition, feature interaction analysis, feature location/feature mining, feature modularity, and many more.

instructions.instruction: true

property.name: org.eclipse.equinox.p2.description
property.value:
Java Editor for CIDE, based on the JDT Editor. With syntax highlighting, type-checking, etc. Open Java files with the "Colored Compilation Unit Editor".
Additionally import and export of annotated Java code to AHEAD, FeatureHouse, AspectJ, CPP, and Munge is provided (experimental)
